figure_1.title: Figure 1.
figure_1.caption: The universal patient pathway for breast cancer management is illustrated in 3 sequential care episodes: patient interval, diagnostic interval, and treatment interval.

figure_2.title: Figure 2.
figure_2.caption: The paradigm of breast cancer early detection is illustrated.26 BSE indicates breast self-examination.

figure_3.title: Figure 3.
figure_3.caption: A paradigm of early breast cancer detection using population-based screening is shown.26

claims.sentence:
After final acceptance by the co-chairs and BHGI review team, all individual manuscripts were coordinated for internal referencing as data for one or multiple consensus statements.BREAST HEALTH SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS
To frame the systematic analysis and presentation for the BHGI Summit, BHGI developed a universal patient pathway for breast cancer management divided into three sequential episodes of care (Figure 1).

This patient pathway is based on the principles of current breast cancer detection, diagnosis and treatment strategies that are required in all resource settings based on the known biological features of the disease:
Figure 1.

Early diagnosis based on prompt and accurate clinical assessment without mammographic screening can downstage invasive cancer29 and predictably improve outcomes for all breast cancer patients, whereas less than half of breast cancers are screen-detected even in the most effective screening programs.30 Early diagnosis strategies are appropriate for resource-constrained settings, because the number of patients with clinical symptoms requiring diagnostic evaluation is more manageable and higher yield (by an order of magnitude) than the number of women from asymptomatic screened populations requiring screening and additional diagnostic imaging studies (Figure 2).

Early diagnosis strategies for symptomatic patients are also necessary for the evaluation and work-up of younger patients who are too young to be appropriate screening candidates (even in high income settings).31
Figure 2.
Once these early diagnosis goals have been addressed, then a healthcare system can be prepared to initiate resource-appropriate screening programs (Figure 3).
